conclusion: Point charge +q is located at A(0,0,h) above an infinite conducting plane at z = 0.
The field in the region z > 0 can be obtained with the image-charge method.
Replace the conductor by an image charge –q located at the mirror point (0,0,–h).
Everywhere in the vacuum (z > 0) the potential and field produced by the real and image charges satisfy the required boundary condition V = 0 on the plane.
The electric field at any point r in the vacuum is the superposition of the fields produced by the real charge +q and the image charge –q.
Point P(h, h, –h) lies inside the conductor (z-coordinate is –h < 0).
Inside the conductor the total electrostatic field must vanish: Etotal(P) = Ereal(P) + Einduced(P) = 0 for z ≤ 0.
The magnitude of the field generated by the induced charges at P is the magnitude of the field produced by the external point charge +q alone, with the opposite sign.
Compute the distance from the real charge at A(0,0,h) to P(h, h, –h): |AP| = h√6.
The magnitude of the electric field produced at that point by charge +q is |Ereal| = k q / (6h²).
The magnitude of the electric field generated by the induced surface charges at the point (h, h, –h) is E = k q / (6 h²).
